description: Reading/writing files, pathlib, file modes, relative vs absolute paths

cards.front: What is the with statement and why use it for files?
cards.back:
with guarantees the file is closed when the block ends, even if an error occurs.

with open("data.txt") as f:
    contents = f.read()
# f is automatically closed here

Without with, you must manually call f.close() and risk forgetting.

cards.front: What are the file modes "r", "w", and "a"?
cards.back:
"r" — read (default). File must exist.
"w" — write. Creates new file or OVERWRITES existing.
"a" — append. Adds to end of existing file.

with open("out.txt", "w") as f:
    f.write("Hello!")

Be careful with "w" — it erases existing content!

cards.front: What is pathlib and why is it better than string paths?
cards.back:
pathlib provides an object-oriented API for file paths.

from pathlib import Path
p = Path("data/sample.txt")
p.exists()    # check if file exists
p.name        # "sample.txt"
p.stem        # "sample"
p.suffix      # ".txt"
p.parent      # Path("data")
p.read_text() # read entire file

Works cross-platform. No manual path string joining.

cards.front: What is the difference between relative and absolute paths?
cards.back:
Absolute: full address from root
  /Users/alice/projects/data.txt
  C:\Users\alice\projects\data.txt

Relative: address from current directory
  data.txt
  ../other_folder/file.txt

.. means "go up one folder."

cards.front: How do you read a file line by line?
cards.back:
with open("data.txt") as f:
    for line in f:
        line = line.strip()  # remove newline
        print(line)

The for loop reads one line at a time — memory efficient.
Always .strip() to remove trailing newline characters.

cards.front: What is a common Windows path mistake in Python?
cards.back:
Backslash is an escape character. \n becomes a newline.

# WRONG:
path = "C:\Users\alice\new_file.txt"  # \n is newline!

# FIX 1: Escaped backslashes
path = "C:\\Users\\alice\\new_file.txt"

# FIX 2: Raw string
path = r"C:\Users\alice\new_file.txt"

# FIX 3: Forward slashes (always work)
path = Path("C:/Users/alice/new_file.txt")

cards.front: What error do you get if a file does not exist and how do you fix it?
cards.back:
FileNotFoundError if the file is not at the given path.

Fixes:
1. Check the filename for typos
2. Make sure you are in the right directory
3. Use Path.exists() to check first:

from pathlib import Path
if Path("data.txt").exists():
    contents = Path("data.txt").read_text()

cards.front: Why should you always strip() lines when reading a file?
cards.back:
Each line from a file includes a trailing newline character (\n).

for line in open("data.txt"):
    print(line)  # Double-spaced! Each line has \n + print adds \n

Fix:
    print(line.strip())  # Removes leading/trailing whitespace and \n
